byline.contributor: Dionne Searcey and Sergey Ponomarev contributed reporting.

abstract: Top American and allied military officials warn of growing concern about Islamic State group's Libya branch, which has doubled in numbers even as group's size in Iraq and Syria has been reduced to around 25,000 from high of around 31,500 members; group is attempting to carve out caliphate in Libya and there are indications it is trying to set up statelike institutions there; concern is growing even as Pres Obama is considering whether to approve broad use of military force in country.
lead_paragraph: As U.S. intelligence agencies say the number of Islamic State fighters in Iraq and Syria has dropped, the group’s ranks in Libya have roughly doubled.

headline.main: U.S. Scrambles to Contain Growing ISIS Threat in Libya
headline.print_headline: U.S. Scrambles to Beat Back ISIS in Libya

snippet: As U.S. intelligence agencies say the number of Islamic State fighters in Iraq and Syria has dropped, the group’s ranks in Libya have roughly doubled.
